abstract.p: Letter by Lorraine Mesagna on Jan 30 article pollution caused by SUV's and ways to reduce air pollution and global warming; says she accomplised this by getting rid of her SUV

block.p: In ''Even S.U.V. Drivers Can Find Ways to Hug a Tree'' (Personal Business, Jan. 30), Matthew L. Wald detailed a number of interesting ways to save energy and to reduce our contributions to global warming.

In ''Even S.U.V. Drivers Can Find Ways to Hug a Tree'' (Personal Business, Jan. 30), Matthew L. Wald detailed a number of interesting ways to save energy and to reduce our contributions to global warming.

I had a sport utility vehicle a few years back. It was great to drive while seated up high; I could see everything. I loved the power of the V-8 engine. With it, of course, I never had trouble moving from the on-ramp onto the expressway.
I can attest that the bulk of sport utilities can be lifesaving: I was able to walk out of the emergency room the night that another S.U.V. forced me into the path of a dump truck.

Yet the fact that my S.U.V. could never eke out more than 12 miles a gallon continually needled my environmental conscience. I finally repented in a way that the article did not suggest: I got rid of it.
